I usually get the tacos, they have different kinds of meats you can choose from including fish and veggie. My favorite is the lengua tacos, the meat is cooked very well. The tortilla is kinda of soggy. Comes with a side of beans and green sauce. They also have this spicy sauce that you can use, but its pretty spicy for me. They also serve plates and burritos.

Overall, pretty good place to grab quick tacos!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Came across Uno Dos Tacos one night in SF, and was pleasantly surprised by the interior of the place after having it look like some typical FiDi restaurant.

I wasn't super hungry so I figured a carne asada taco would be enough, and my boyfriend ordered a carne asada burrito- we didn't go for the happy hour foods which seem to be there only for happy hour.

The carne asada burrito had rice, meat, beans, and cheese. Flavor wasn't really there and it seemed like they had skimped out on the meat...
The carne asada taco was tastier and a good portion of meat. It came with a lime and green salsa, and I'd recommend the taco over a burrito!

The lady who took our order was nice- I wasn't feeling very well and wanted hot water and she was able to give me some (so, good service & ok food)
author: Mary F.

description: I've only had the chicken tinga salad here which is good but I'd love to try more next time (maybe even for happy hour at the tequila bar). I do wish that they had a few more options as far as toppings go for salads - it would be especially nice if we could add guac or peppers/onions. However, the portion is good for the price and the flavor is on point. It's never too crowded when I come here for lunch so service is pretty fast with my food coming out within 5 minutes or so. Overall, it's a solid option for a good meal in the area.
author: Pooja C.

description: Very affordable breakfast burritos and solid tacos. Great happy hour prices for food and drinks!
author: Nathan D.

description: Worst Mexican food. Only come if interested in margaritas. Good price margarita but food is absolutely not authentic whatsoever. Gross tasting meat.
author: Robby V.

description: Uno Dos tacos has the best breakfast burritos in the FiDi. I've tried five other places, and Uno Dos has my breakfast burrito heart.
author: Daisy W.

description: This place has a decent Happy house and a really good bar. But the food here is out of a plastic bag and heated. Got a burrito and it had couple of veggies and rest was filled with black beans. Might as well call it a bean burrito
author: Jt G.

description:
Why this place charges 9 bucks for a burrito with 3 bland things in it I'll never know. Chicken was meh, black beans were nothing special, the "Salsa Fresca" was basically chopped tomato.

No lime. No spice. No sour cream. NO RICE. 

And cheese was extra. I will not be back.
- One Very Disappointed Latina.
author: Gwendolyn R.

description:
This place is so cute especially that they have outdoor sitting. It huge. Enough space to sit during rush hours in the FIDI. 

Came here with 2 friends and we shared the 6 tacos special. One of each taco from their menu. If you want to change anything, additional charge. My favorite was their carnitas and their fried fish taco. But everything was still very tasty. Even their veggie taco and I'm that person whom prefers meat over anything. They serve the tacos with 3 different salsa. Mild, medium and spicy. Best combo is mild with spicy. YUM! They do provide a salsa bottle at each tables. 

We order a side of chips and guacamole for under $4 dollars. Wish there was more guacamole but if you run out, the salsa does the trick as well. Food was made fast and services good. Will definitely come back.
author: Sandy B.

description:
High quality, well priced, Tex-Mex!

It's easy to understand the lines at Uno Dos Tacos.  I got in right as the line was forming before the lunch rush and soon saw it stretch down the street.  Tex-Mex isn't a complicated cuisine, but Uno Dos uses the right quality of ingredients and spices to tantilize your tastebuds into taco bliss.

I had a pork belly burrito, stuffed with savory pork belly, crispy bacon, and fresh black beans.  And unlike other Tex-Mex places that use rice to artificially boost the size of their food without adding flavor, Uno Dos's burritos have little to no rice, as I couldn't find any as I devoured my food.

Service was increadibly fast considering the speed at which they take orders.  I was in and out of the place in less than 10 minutes with food in hand.  My entire meal was under $8, which for San Francisco is rare, and makes me want to come back to try more food.

Nothing bad can be said about this affordable Tex-Mex wonder!
author: Nadav P.

description: Good taco joint and awesome patio on a nice day.  Will come back here for lunch when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Brian N.

description:
I have tried a lot of tacos and Uno Dos still takes the #1 spot. The staff is so friendly and the food is delicious - tinga tacos are my personal favorite. Their prices are also very affordable, especially for SF. 

Great place to grab food and drinks with friends after work, especially in the summertime.
author: Kristin O.

description: One of my go-to places for lunch near the office. I don't usually eat much Mexican food, but I love the carnitas plate here. The lunch line grows pretty quickly around 12, however they're also quite fast/efficient so I've never had to wait too long for my order.
author: Tak K.

description: Great happy hour/dinner spot in the financial district. Prices are affordable for the area. Got an strawberry agua fresca, chips and salsa, and a veggie taco for all less than $10. Plenty of seating inside and outside. Great place to bring your team or catch up with friends after work.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Get:
Chicharrones Burrito - tis wonderful
Meat  + Salad - good portion and tasty for a "lighter" lunch


Get insanely packed during lunch and HH.
author: Steven F.

description: Came here with a few coworkers after a work happy hour. I ordered the happy hour quesadilla. I was served with empanadas, instead. When I asked the server, confused, I could tell she was also confused, but she didn't want to deal with correcting it so instead she said to be, rushed, "these are quesadillas," when clearly they were not. I was starving and didn't want to delay it any further, so just took it. Bad service. Would've been a good deal if I actually got my quesadilla. A lot of outdoor seating, good deal on sangria pitchers.
author: Marie D.

description: Vegetarian burrito is full of veggies and flavorful, not boring like at many taquerias.
author: Brendan M.

description:
Came here for happy hour on a Wednesday around 6:30PM.  Surprisingly not as crowded as I would imagine but still very lively inside.  There's a patio area and our group of 6 took advantage of the decent weather outside.  My friend also tells me they provide blankets for colder nights....interesting concept.  Hopefully they wash their blankets regularly.  Overall cool environment.

Happy hour deals here are pretty meh.  Everything on the menu (not HH prices) are pretty high so I think happy hour just brings the prices to a reasonable amount.  Regardless, the food here is pretty good!  One of my friends and I shared a plate of their six taco plate ($16 and comes with one fish and one lengua already - any additional taco of those costs an extra $1).  The tacos were pretty standard - nothing mind-blowing, if anything it was just basic.  We got 2 carne asada and 2 chicken.  Chicken tasted a little weird, but carne asada was good.  The fish was probably the best.

We also got baskets on baskets of chips and salsa/guac.  I don't normally like chunky salsa and guac, but they were actually really good!  The guac tasted fresh and I dipped my chips in the salsa sauce (I don't like tomatoes) and that had a great spice and kick to it.  I think the chips and guac/salsa were my favorite thing we had - I know, so basic.  But they really were tasty!

A margarita pitcher is almost $30.  It probably served 5 cups.  A little pricey in my opinion, but they were strong so I guess that justifies the price a little.
author: Michelle B.

description: Food was great. Location is convenient and staff is very friendly. I had the guacamole and chips it was amazing, had the perfect amount of lime and salt. Also had a carnita and lengua taco which we're also great, just wish they would've told me it comes with  onions and cilantro but it was still great. Also had the happy hour gordita which actually comes with 2, they were the perfect size! Would definitely return when back in the area!
author: Celina M.

description: so delicious, in such a vibrant downtown part of the city. options for everyone, and the best tortilla chips on earth.
author: Auri V.

description: Love uno dos awesome place love the employees and the drinks the food is amazing. Happy hour is my favorite time to go just love it
author: Gabby S.

description:
Coming from Texas, I was shocked at how much food costs in the city.  For the price, this place was perfect.  It reminded me of Freebirds or Chipolte.  When we got here (545) the place was slammed so I expected the worst.  Line was short, so therefore food came out at a reasonable speed.  

Food was pretty good. The salad had A LOT of black beans and a good portion of meat.  Overall 4/5 

Burrito - enough to fill up my husband.  Slightly smaller than a Chipolte burrito - size of a Hybrid (Freebirds) 5/5

Taco- tiny, if you eat it without the tortilla and beans like my child did. But recommended get 2-3. 3/ 5

Happy hour 5/5 - can't beat HH and $4.50 drafts. 

And they give you a blanket to borrow when you're cold!
author: April S.

description:
Overpriced, and not very tasty. I have been to Uno Dos a couple of times, and getting sick the most recent time was the end. I had it catered at work only to get sick a couple hours later.

I have tried their burritos, salads and tacos, and all are ehhh. The tacos meat is always dry (steak), the fried fish is tasty but I have had better, and the chicken is tasteless compared to other places.

The burrito is only beans, meat and salsa, no rice, which is a let down for $8 burrito.

If I want tacos, I rather do the taco truck (Tacos El Autlense) outside Hotsy Totsy in Albany. tacos cost $1.50 and is hands down 100x better.
author: Mei L.

description: A bustling and happy place. The menu is simple and there are a bunch of options for the vegetarians too. Since it is just off market street, makes it an easy  place to grab a quick lunch with a colleague. The burritos are not as big as they usually are. Staff is friendly and the food gets done real quick. Watch out for the wait times during busy hours though.
author: Sumana S.

description: I was quite pleased with my lunch. Got there early, 11:30, and was served with 5 minutes. I had the Carne Asada Salad - delicious. The place is kept clean and I noticed blankets you can use if you sit outside (SF weather). This will be one of my lunch spots from now on.
author: Ken A.

description:
Came here at prime lunch time on a week day. The long line initially almost caused us to leave, but we stuck with it. Surprisingly, the line moves quickly and they get the food out fast. Like, really fast maybe 5 minutes. Which is great. 

Whenever I walk by Uno, whether it's during lunch or happy hour, it consistently looks busy and crowded. There's a good amount of seating inside and outside, so you don't have to worry about finding a table. 

I ordered two fish tacos, which is what one of the employees recommended as a normal serving size. I wouldn't get more than two unless you're really very hungry. 
The price was right at about $9.50 after tax, especially for San Francisco. The tacos themselves were fine - classic fried fish with cabbage and tomatoes. There's salsa on the tables that you put on your meal that adds a spicy kick and a bit more flavor. 

You get your bang for your buck. The food is good but nothing amazing.
author: Chelsea N.

description:
In Jersey for lunch we eat a variety of things- pizza, sub sandwiches, salads, sushi...the list goes on and on. When I'm in SF we eat tacos, and lots of them. And I wouldn't have it any other way.

The menu is quick and easy. Choose your protein (asada, chicken, carnitas, fish) and then choose your style. You can order your protein in various forms including taco, burrito, salad or platter. 

I went with the asada platter- a hearty portion of juicy steak neatly plated next to a heaping mound of black beans and pico de gallo. There are also corn tortillas on the side so you can opt to make your own taco if you wish. If you are going to get tacos I vote to go with the platter because you can put way more meat in it! The meat was a bit flavorless so next time I'd probably order a side of guac to mix things up a bit. Otherwise, the platter was perfect as is. 

There is also ample seating outside, so if you need an office escape and want some fresh air then this is a good move. Hopefully I can come back for another lunch next time I'm in SF!
author: Sara B.
Candice G.

description:
Wanted to check out something different in this neighborhood, and I was famished, and I was right nearby. The place looked cute and Mexican sounded good, so in I went.

Loved the atmosphere, the vibe, the chill energy. Loved the outdoor seating. Prices are a little high, but it's San Francisco and it's downtown, so no surprise... I ordered two items off of the happy hour menu, and a soda, so dropped about $14 with tax and tip.

TINY portions. It's definitely more finger food to nosh on than FOOD food for when you want dinner. I could have had 5 of these for a meal, which would have been $25, which would have been kind of not in the spirit of a cheap happy hour out. Tasted nice, but seriously, there's lots of places that are less fancy that have as-good of food for half the price.

Not that impressed. Too pricey for what you get.
author: Sean B.

description:
I've never had a bad time at Uno Dos Tacos. Located just off Market St in the heart of downtown, Uno Dos Tacos is an easily accessible place to get your taco fix, with plenty of indoor and outdoor seating. On cold days, you can borrow a free blanket if you plan to sit outside.

It may not be the most authentic taco place in SF, but the tacos are quite delicious, and the guacamole is bomb! I'm especially a fan of the pescado (fried fish) and asada (beef) tacos. If you get chips and guac on the side, two tacos is plenty for a filling meal. And did I mention the guacamole is awesome? It's a little more lemon-y than average which gives it a little bit of a kick.

They also serve a variety of drinks at the bar, including margaritas. Great place to grab dinner and drinks with a few friends, or host a crowd!
author: Brittany C.

description: Great place for a work lunch in the Financial District. Reasonably priced, but their portions are pretty small. I wouldn't say their food is anything out of the ordinary. Plenty of outdoor seating on a warm day.
author: Ciera P.

description: Went there after a day at SFMOMA. I ordered 2 chicken tinga tacos.  They were absolutely delish. They come with black beans which were also good. I would definitely go there again. Not too far from SFMOMA. They have inside seating and outside seating.
author: Debi L.

description: Uno Dos Tacos is my husband, Shawn, and my "Go-To" spot on Fridays! It was also our place of choice to have our friends to fellowship on Friday, October 6th, the night before our wedding. To our surprise, there was enough room for all of our guests because the restaurant is always packed - however, there seems to always be enough space for us to dine comfortably. Great atmosphere, delicious tacos, and the margaritas are far from disappointing! A HUGE SHOUTOUT to Sandy (the bartender) who makes us feel welcome every time we walk through the door.
author: William W.

description: This place is awesome. I got a steak burrito with cheese. Similar to La Taqueria, they don't put rice in their burritos but they make up for it with the abundant flavors from the beans, homemade salsa and delicious tender meat. The burrito is a bit on the smaller size but in this case quality means much more. For a burrito place on busy market street it is well worth it it. Price is expected. I paid $8.75 for my Asada burrito and the line went surprisingly fast. Seating on a rainy is limited and a bit loud but in the end you will go here for the food!
author: Corrin A.

description:
Went there to try the burrito breakfast, it was great :) 
Not too big for a breakfast, fast and cheap. A lots of seat and free wi-fi, the waitress was nice.
author: Yannick G.

description:
Welp, not getting coffee with my breakfast burritos anymore. Gross. I most likely won't be going back as there is a great breakfast burrito competition in the area. 

Two stars for the burrito being good.
author: Miles K.

description:
I recently went to Uno Dos Tacos on a weekday evening. It was loud with cramped seating yet the food was served in generous portions. I ordered chips & salsa for $1.95 plus tax. It came in a big portion that would be best to split as these might be too big a portion for one person. The salsa it came with was pico de gallo & very heavy based on the tomatoes yet could have used a bit more jalapeño for heat in addition to cilantro or garlic for flavor. 

I also ordered the vegetariano veggie plate for $7.75 plus tax. This came with roasted squash, poblano, onion, mushroom, corn, tortillas, beans, & salsa fresca. The corn tortillas are made in house daily w/ fresh masa & were the highlight of the meal as they were fresh as you could imagine. 

The hot sauce looked made in house & was good yet felt some of the heat was toned down otherwise in the cuisine to suit a western palate.
author: Shane S.

description:
Uno. Dos. Taco! That's the speed of how fast your tacos are ready after you ordered and to your mouth!

My team and I came here for taco tuesday and boy was it busy! The line was out the door but good thing it moved pretty fast! I got a pescado (fish $4.50) taco and a lengua (beef tongue $3.50) taco and they were both really good! The fish was crispy and with the lime and salsa was perfect. Remember to grab a lot of napkins because your tacos will be dripping with sauce and meat juice. We also got the chips and guac and their chips were freshly fried and hot when we got them. The guac was pretty standard and I wished the portion was more. 

They got a patio with umbrellas outside so it's great when it's a nice day out. Super busy during lunch hours and happy hours. Actually, this place is always crackin whenever I pass by so they must be that good! Plus a few points for being super close to where I work!
author: Hoyan L.

description:
Good place for drinks and tapas. Good place for large groups - if you get there early. 

Service was good.
author: Jason J.

description:
Is it the most authentic taco ever? No! Is it on market street and really fresh, tasty, and close to where you work? Yes! 

Definitely too expensive, but definitely better than eating at Chipotle!
author: Hajir S.

description:
Prior to coming here, my friend told me that the food here isn't as authentic so I had relatively low standards. However once I got here, I was surprised to see a patio area outside and that it was also relatively busy for happy hour. This restaurant is also one of those order at the counter and get a number type settings.

For drinks, my party and I ordered margaritas and sangria. Although I am neither a Margarita or Sangria expert, I was a big fan of the Margaritas as the taste of alcohol was well blended in. However, I have had better Sangria in the past, as I felt the Sangria tasted a bit too much like dried grapes. Would definitely recommend the Margarita over the Sangria.

For food, the nacho and chip portions are huge! Definitely enough for you + 1 or more. In addition, I also got a fish taco and a flauntas. The fish taco is well made, like most other fish tacos out there, and comes with a bean paste on the side. It was my first time having in fluntas. The taste was rather spicy, and they were a lot smaller than expected. My friend also stated the same, so the fluntas may not be an ideal dish here. 

I would give this place a 3.5 stars if I can. I was happy about the Margarita and Fish Taco here, but I felt the Sangria and Fluntas could be better.
author: Galen W.

description: Uno Dos does what it sets out to do really well, which is to speedily provide a matrix of not particularly authentic Mexican food options with plenty of beer and/or margaritas. While that may not sound like a ringing endorsement, I think it's a great option in the area, and the only downside is that it can get really crowded. Working nearby, I came by at all sorts of times to celebrate, drown our sorrows, or both, and have seen plenty of others doing the same. I also think the food is quite decent!
author: Lisa K.

description:
I organized a happy hour last friday for my company . . .  that I found out about on Thursday O___o

Have no fear! Uno Dos Tacos is here!

I called and spoke to a woman named Maria; she was incredibly kind and helpful, assuring me that they would be able to fulfill my last minute request. And boy did they! 

The next afternoon I had a beautiful taco bar spread, delivered by an incredibly helpful gentleman who worked with me to make sure the setup was Just Right. 

Everyone LOVED the food - the guac and the fish tacos were the biggest hit, fyi. 

I definitely recommend Uno Dos for your catering needs! And a big shout out to Maria for making all our Taco Dreams come true :)
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This place needs a higher rating than 3.5 stars.  Let me help you out, Uno Dos Tacos, and hopefully bump your rating up to a nice healthy 4 stars.  The big draw of this place is that their happy hour lasts from 4 until closing!  So relax, take a blanket, which are available to the right of the entrance, and enjoy the patio, where San Francisco summers are disappointingly cool and windy.

To your left, you will find the bar, and to your right, you will find the counter where you shall order your food.  Naturally, gravitated to the left side of the restaurant, and found myself talking to a chirpy bartender.  I asked which drink has the higher alcohol content--the margarita or the sangria.  She said that the sangria seems stronger because it has brandy in it.  Say no more.  $20 later, I had a pitcher in my hand and I was ready to party (not by myself, but with two of my girl friends).  The pitcher was enough for us to get a good tipsy feeling going on, but then again, we are all relatively lightweights.  

The food was delicious!  We got a sopas (never had it before--was like chicharon on a tart), and flautas (I LOVE flautas! I wish the happy hour portion was bigger, but it was only $5 anyway), and my woman friends got tacos.  We had chips and some very good chunky guac to start off, and it already got us full.  However, not to be deterred, we still finished all of our food.  The only thing is, it took FOREVER to get our food; to the point where I had to get up and ask the person nearby the kitchen what the hold up was.  

Awesome happy hour, drinks, and food!  I'd come back here, but bring a snickers bar in case the kitchen is taking awhile...it will be worth it, though!
author: Annie A.

description: I love this place! Really great tacos, burritos, chips are amazing and not too pricey.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Food is ok. We had the beef & shrimp tacos and they were just fine. Nothing too great but nothing to complain about either. I guess they were lacking flavor 

The service is quick. The drinks are just OK
author: Naksh C.

description: I'm hear every morning for breakfast (love their egg burritos) and they have the best home made salsa you've ever had in your life.  Yum!
author: Paul Z.

description:
Stopped in here for a weekday lunch with a couple business partners from out of town. We came in around noon and while there was a line, it moved along quickly. The menu is like a pre-set Chipotle, where you pick your meat (pork, chicken, beef, veggie) and the form it comes in (bowl, tacos, salad, plate) - super, super quick! 

Prices are around $8, and the food you get will be way better than any $10 sandwich you'll find in the area. Sit down with your buzzer and in 5 or so minutes you've got a bowl full of fresh, tasty grub. The tomatillo-based salsa they have is excellent, and chips are crispy without being oily. This is a lot like Tex-Mex food I cook at home - I'd be happy to come back here anytime. 

They play music indoors that can make having a serious business meeting a little ridiculous, so either grab a margarita and give up on that ish or take it outside to the picnic tables. There's tons of seating - room for everyone! Check em' out.
author: Laura B.

description:
Great food!
Great happy hour. Went on a Friday HH ended at 8 or so. Bartenders are awesome, really friendly. Their Micheladas are amazing, they make their own mix, they don't use the Bloody Mary mix like everyone else. Best Micheladas in the city. #happyhourqueen
author: Kristina R.

description: This place is amazing! I will be a regular here all thanks to Sandy and Rodolfo! They are nothing but great PLUS they make the best micheladas in the city! The flautas are also amazing. The tacos are great.
author: Iviz M.

description:
Holy Guacamole!! My Carne Asada burrito was literally exploding with guacamole and sour cream; two of my favorite things ever. {Note: These heavenly items don't come standard, I added them to their already fabulous burrito creation.} The burrito was also packed with black beans, pico & cheese. 

Did I mentioned the guacamole? ;) It's amazing and you must, at the very least, order a side of guac & chips! I loved their salsa in the 'squeeze' bottles. I honestly wanted to squeeze it in my mouth, I couldn't get enough. The chips were super fresh and I'm pretty positive that the corn tortillas are made right there on site! They also have a tequila bar if you feel like adding a snazzy spirit to the mix! 

Looking for a colorful, fun spot to grab lunch or dinner with a friend or coworker in the city? This is it!! They also have a lovely {large} patio which is always a plus in beautiful Cali!
author: Hailey P.

description:
As soon as you turn onto 2nd at Market, an inviting outdoor patio with large yellow umbrellas immediately grabs your attention. When you step inside to order, the bustling atmosphere, upbeat music, and affordable options make Uno Dos Tacos a fun lunch destination in SoMa.

It's simple to order: you just choose your meat (beef/chicken/pork), fish, or veggie and then your preparation (taco, burrito, salad, or plate). I like the tinga chicken plate, which comes with homemade tortillas, salsa, and black beans. The margaritas are great, too! 

The staff is super friendly and the dishes are prepared quickly. With reasonable pricing (from $7-9) for a great lunch, Uno Dos Tacos scores in my book.
author: Shira W.

description:
Such a deal! $8-9 for a big plate of upscale Mexican grub? I could get used to this. 

We went for lunch and were really impressed with the simple-to-navigate menu & spacious seating both inside and out. There's also a bar area, which makes Uno Dos a great happy hour destination too. Basically, you pick your meat (or fish or veg), then pick a "style" to enjoy it in: taco, burrito, salad, or plate. Super easy to make a decision! 

I picked the vegetarian main + salad option; roasted veggies on farmers market lettuce (not just boring romaine), with black beans, queso fresco and guac (additional charge). 

Food was ready in about 5 mins, and we grabbed a nice table outside on their patio. Unlike most SOMA lunch spots, Uno Dos was not a crazy scene. In fact, it felt like a little oasis away from the city. For less than $10 per person, this is more than a great meal, but a darling little spot to put in the lunch rotation.
author: Nique F.

description:
This places has a short menu that they execute very...very well.  They even make their corn tortillas in house.

Add that to good prices and a FULL TEQUILA BAR, yup they earned five stars.
author: ADAM f.

description:
I absolutely LOVE Uno Dos - the vibe is casual and fun and they have hands down the best breakfast burritos in the area for only $3.50! I normally add bacon and avocado, which bumps them up a buck, but they are so delicious. My team and I make it a weekly outing every Friday morning and I am so so tempted to go every morning - they are too good! Come for the breakfast burritos by 10:3am and don't be intimidated by the lines since they go quickly. 

Uno Dos is also so great for lunch/ a casual dinner. The guac and tacos are delicious and also inexpensive for this area. Apparently they have a great happy hour as well. Yay Uno Dos!
author: Frankie I.

description: I have been working in San Francisco downtown for about 5 months. Everytime I look up lunch options on yelp, this restaurant always pops up. I ignored it because of the 3.5 rating. We finally made it there yesterday and I was pleasantly surprised. There was a huge line which cleared very quickly. We got the food very quickly. I ordered the chicken and fish tacos  which came with bean paste and salsa. I took my first bite of the chicken taco and Oh My God, I was blown away by how flavorful it was. I didn't even need salsa on it. The salsa was spicy just how I like it. The fish taco was also good. Good music, good drinks. I would say this is a must visit for all who like eating spicy food and good tacos. Pretty much my regular spot for lunch.
author: Jahnabee B.

description:
Went in around 7pm and the place was packed but we found seating pretty comfortably. I had a tinga burrito and a michelada. the michelada was a little strong but the burrito was great! Even though it did not have rice it was pretty filling and the chicken was deliciously cooked and marinated. The salsa is amazing and just a little goes a long way, I definitely ate more of my burrito than I should have because of the salsa!

The staff was great, the waiter helped me carry the plates and glasses to our table becasue he saw me struggling and they also have cute blankets you can use for when it gets cold out. Will definitely be back for the food and drinks.
author: Rachel N.

description:
I'm still a little dismayed that this spot is a new place.  I went to the old place on my first day of work at my current job.  Six years ago.  Also, I had about exactly 24 hours of experience in San Francisco and California that day.

Uno Dos Tacos is adequate food, some drink options, above average service and cleanliness, and a great space in a good location.  I come here for lunch on Saturdays because not a lot is open in this neck of the woods.  I've had tacos all three times, and I always get a mix.  The food is good quality, but a little dry.  Clearly it's not cheap meat, which can ruin a good taco.  The side sauce is good, but you only get one option so far as I know.  The tacos come with a small side of Black Beans which are tasty.  I've tried Carne Asada, Chicken, and Carnitas tacos.

I think this place really shines because of the space and location.  And, for that matter, the availability on the weekend.  The interior is spacious and open.  The line and kitchen is completely unshielded, but you have plenty of space between it and the seating area.  They also have a huge patio outside on 2nd (very close to Market).  That's where I ate my first ever lunch in SF.  ... Nostalgia.  

Two final notes:

1.  They have alcohol, but it is at a separate counter from where you get food.  Not sure what that's all about.  I've never drank here.
2.  They have Breakfast Burritos during the week.  Also, I've not tried.  Yet.  Soon.
author: Adam S.

description:
I don't know what took me so long to try this place considering its proximity to the office, but I will definitely be back for breakfast... and lunch... and happy hour...

- AMAZING homemade corn tortillas, first of all
- It's pricey if you are like me and used to paying $1.50 for tacos in certain parts of Oakland, but given the location and clientele, $3.50 or whatever is honestly not that bad.
- CHICHARRONES. You need this. 
- Really good, spicy, TASTY salsa. Your asshole will be mad, but your taste buds will thank you.
- Vegetarian tacos: meh, and the option to add cheese shouldn't be 50 cents. Sorry vegetarians, there's a Mixt Greens or something a block away.

Overall a delicious experience!
author: Aivy C.

description:
Uno Dos Tacos is one of my favorite spots for Happy Hour. I've been here a few times, mainly to take advantage of the post-work Happy Hour specials that run most of the night. Our favorite margarita is the "La Paloma" -- which we normally get a few pitchers of!

The food is decent, and decently priced. Nothing *too* special, but nothing awful either. Just some decent Tex Mex. I had the Asada salad, and though the meat was cooked well and tasted good, I found the rest of the salad itself was bland. To make up for it, I had to douse the lettuce in salsa. Not bad but not really my thing. My friends had the Asada, Tinga, and Carnitas tacos. They actually found the Asada to be overcooked, though they enjoyed the Tinga and Carnitas tacos. 

So yes, you can probably find way better Mexican food in the Mission, but if you're looking for a fun, casual, post-work vibe, this is a great spot. Take advantage of the margarita pitchers! :)
author: Rachel F.

description:
Overall, flavorless Mexican. Not bad, but nothing memorbale. I however do have to give it up for those homemade, thick corn tortillas! They are bomb! Everything else, kind of gringoized.

You order at the front, grab a number and go find a seat. Inside is spacious and there is plenty of outdoor seating on their patio. Great for groups in a casual setting if you can snag some seating.

You have the the usual suspects: tacos, burriton, quesadillas, plate, etc...  I ended up with the chicken plate that comes with a nice little mound of chicken, black beans and three tortillas. I had to slather their non spicy hot sauce to get any flavor and even then, the star of the show were those tortillas. Where's the spice? Where's the heat? Honesty, where is it?

Bonus: that guac is good! Not the biggest portion, but super fresh and delicious. Chips, freshly fried, albeit a bit greasy. Again, salsa was super weak. 

Solid portions, a great space, with some great value. A million miles away from authentic and definitely lacking flavor that would make this a four star Mexican joint.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
What? Lunch under $10? And it's a salad? Okay, maybe not the best salad you've ever had with the most ingredients but it's a solid salad with generous portions.

I've had the chicken taco salad and the carnitas taco salad, each of which comes to less than $10. I preferred the carnitas because (naturally) the meat was very delicious. The salad is very basic - romaine lettuce, salsa, meat, cheese and beans; you can add other stuff like guacamole at a price. This isn't a fancy salad but it does the job. 

The salads come out quickly and - even on a nice day - there are a decent number of seats available.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Thursday at noon and it was fairly busy but the line moved quickly.  The outside seating area is bigger than inside.  They offered blankets which was nice on a chilly day as the outdoors area only gets a little sun, I sat inside to observe the staff and flow though.  The staff was nice and the place was clean with the open kitchen being really clean too.

I got three tacos, the Asada, the Carnitas and the special of the day Chicken Mole.  The special was amazing!  By far the best taco I had and really delicious.  The other two were a little dry and bland.  Had the special not been so amazing they may have been better but they just didn't stack up that day.  All three were under $10 total so it was a great deal.

I'd go back to try the others and whatever they had on special for sure.
author: Scott M.

description:
Tacos were delicious! I got the lengua, pescado & asada tacos. Lengua was my favorite. They have indoor and outdoor seating. Good for on the go too! Their angua fresca is  pretty refreshing.

Will try again when I'm back in SF!
author: Doris P.

description:
Haven't been here for lunch or dinner, but I have been here for their Breakfast Burritos! They are AMAZING! Such a good pick-me-up before (or during) work! I go around 10:00am to beat the "breakfast rush" since I've seen some people stand in line earlier than that. 

The BBs are made pretty quickly, and I get mine in just a matter of minutes. Quick service for a delicious breakfast! Although I have to admit, I love McDonalds Breakfast, there's nothing that beats the quickness and amazing taste of their Breakfast Burritos. 

Thanks Uno Dos Tacos for making my mornings! =)
author: Kyle S.

description: Food is good, drinks are better! Sandy is the best bartender ever. Great smile and amazing energy!
author: Steven F.

description: First time coming here and the food was okay.  Service felt a touch slow compared to the fact that most of the food I saw coming out was just tacos and the crowd that was there.  The Tacos were good but not great, I felt like there was something missing from them.  A extra bit of topping or something would have helped.  That being said, the Salsa was really good.  I'd go back as a after work hang out, but I'm not sure I would go as a first choice for tacos.
author: Christopher B.

description:
I really like coming here for their breakfast burritos since they do give you a decent amount of food for only $3.50 which is better then their nearby competitors who are much more expensive and give less. 

But during lunch time due to the area there are long lines and they move very slowly, but the constancy can vary from time to time. Which is kinda of a bummer when you just want a good burrito or taco.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Awesome chicken salad!! So fresh and tasty! I loved it and recommend it!!! I will go back for sure!!
The chicken was slightly spicy and juicy, just delicious!!
author: Linda C.

description:
A-OK tacos, a bit on the pricey side.

I was in the mood for some street tacos, and this was the closest one to work in the financial district and the reviews were good enough for me to check it out. Located about a half a block from the Montgomery Bart station on Market St., you can find this establishment.

There are helpful signs when you walk in, to the left you'll find the tequila bar, and on the right, you can order food. I wanted to try the tacos, but when scanning the menu, I saw that Salsa and Chips were only $2. I held back from order 3 tacos though, because $3.50 is a little hefty for street tacos, for me at least.

Right after ordering, the cashier attended to grabbing my chips and salsa right away. This was good, because I could snack on something while waiting for my main course. But, I didn't even have to wait that long for them to assemble my two tacos.

The Chips and Salsa were pretty good. I was iffy at first, because I usually like the more well-blended salsas, and theirs is chopped in small cubes, but it turned out to be very good. My problem with it however, is that you get a lot of chips, for just a small container of salsa, I felt weird about asking if I needed to pay the full price for a refill (so if any owners read this review, please let me know if salsa refills cost full price).

I was excited to try the tacos. They're made with your choice of meat, followed with onions and cilantro, all on top of a freshly made masa tortilla. You also get a small container of black beans, and another one with some spicy salsa, with a wedge of lime on the side. I tried my first one with just lime on top. It turned out to be just okay for me though. I was hoping to taste the fresh cilantro and seasoned meat. I could taste them, but I wished they had more flavor. You can add the salsa to add some flavor, but I was hoping that the ingredients would stand out on their own.

With the price and the flavor of the tacos, I can only give a 3 star rating for now. I'll probably come out and try it again sometime, maybe try different meats. Try if you want.
author: Robert O.

description:
"Uno tacos, Dos tacos!"

Or in any language, one taco, two tacos or more made in a hand-made corn tortilla captures my satisfaction. 

I see why this is a very popular Mexican restaurant in the downtown area. 
For $3.25 each, I ordered two tacos with Grilled Pork as my filling. The lean meat was grilled very nicely and complemented very well with the hand-made corn tortilla. 

I also ordered a fat basket of tortilla chips and salsa for $4.50. The chips are also made in-house. And the colorful salsa was fresh with perfect amount of spice. 

The spacious restaurant serves beer and blended cocktails too. 

I dined here on a Saturday and the restaurant is quiet. 

This place is pretty good.
author: Matt G.

description: Some of the best fish tacos i've ever had. Unbelievably good. Also, really good breakfast burritos.
author: Mathias A.

description:
Had a steak, a tinga and a fish tacos. Steak wasn't great but tinga and fish were very a tasty. 

Hand made tortillas are a big plus. Good beer selection also. 

I shall try their breakfast options.
author: Miguel L.

description: Awesome place. Was visiting from dallas and really enjoyed the breakfast. Great atmosphere and def recommend it.
author: James S.

description:
Solid, affordable lunch option in the FiDi hood. Came around 12:30pm on Tuesday. Line wasn't long and there was plenty of seating. I got the beef and chicken (asada and tingua) taco for $3.50 each. They come with a side of black beans topped w/ cotija cheese and 2 salsa varieties. Food tasted as expected. Self serve yourself with utensils, salsa, drinks, etc. 

Overall- good place for a quick bite. Centrally located, so I would come here again. They also have a good happy hour (so I hear).
author: Joanna L.

description:
The breakfast burrito is only 3.50$, and delicious!! Vegetarian friendly, but be careful ordering the veggie tacos (They are super messy!) 
The ambiance is a bit loud after work, but fun nonetheless. With happy hour lasting from 4-close there are some great deals on drinks and food.
The margaritas are strong and delicious. They even gave me a double shot of tequila after they messed up my drink order. 
Would recommend if you are feeling in the mood for Mexican food and in the area.
author: Jeasica C.

description: Pretty good spot! Tasty tacos, guac & chips, and drinks. Not bad prices and good happy hour.
author: Kelly G.

description:
I've walked past here countless times on the way to my office (pretty nostalgic actually; I remember seeing it from the time I first interviewed at my current company), but I've never actually went in. One more time walking past, and I decided I might as well check it out.

Honestly, I can't give the most accurate view of Uno Dos Tacos. I've only had their breakfast burrito, which may not be indicative of how a restaurant's quality is. Let's be real: you really can't mess up a breakfast burrito (actually, you probably can now that I think about it).

I will say though that their breakfast burrito is fantastic. The tortilla doesn't feel too heavy, the ingredients feel pretty fresh; none of that mystery egg and cheese mess you would expect at a sketchier joint.

Some may say that makes it less "authentic" as a real taqueria, but really, I don't mind. It's much more guilt-free.

Plus, the price is right! Compared to other San Francisco breakfast options, I got a breakfast burrito for under $4. For $4, I'd normally get like a piece of toast elsewhere.

I will probably give this joint a real chance if I'm ever feeling Mexican for lunch and don't feel like getting E. coli from Chipotle.

TIP: Breakfast burrito is good!
author: Brian L.

description:
I went for a quick bite to eat at lunch and right off the bat, should have known from the cold reception from the cashier that I should have picked elsewhere to eat. 

Ordered 2 tacos to go - fish and veggie. I made it a point when ordering to speak about the fish and stated I did not eat chicken or red meat. I picked up my order and rushed back to work... only to find I had 1 beef and 1 veggie taco. ... oh well. Unfortunately, 1st impression matters here and with 2 strikes on the same occasion, not likely to visit this place again.
author: Anna M.

description:
Had a craving for a good taco & I am not disappointed. When I walked in, I was relieved to see their corn tortillas are made on-site daily. But, what was better was the quality of the chicken in my Tinga Taco Basket. It melted in my mouth!  

My only complaint (if that's what you want to call it) is the lack of salsa choices. I wish they had habanero salsa or something with a kick. Now, this could've been my fault as I may have overlooked it since it was my first time here & it was crowded. 

Definitely adding this place to my work lunch rotation!
author: Michael B.

description: Great place for happy hour. Love the environment with outdoor seating, bar, quick service and good music. We ordered the taco basket Tinga taco, Flautas and Gorditas. Tacos were great. Well seasoned shredded chicken with their house made chilled sauce and yummy mole. Flautas had the nice crunch under the shredded lettuce. The fried pork on top of the Gorditas was the best park of the meal. The salsa, fresh queso fresco and fried pork were a great combination of textures. I'll be back to try their carnitas and barbacoa tacos.
author: Khoi N.

description:
Ordered 3 asada tacos which came out to a little less than $12 (pricey!). 
I felt like the meat was pretty undercooked and it contained a lot of nerve that was tough to chew! The meat was also pretty flavorless. They give you a cup of refried beans with sprinkled melted cheese and a cup of molcajete-like salsa on the side so I thought that was nice. The beans and salsa were good. BEST PART: The tortillas and made fresh and the machine is visible so you can see when they're coming out hot! After all of this, I was $12 poorer and I was still really hungry.
author: Emanuel U.

description: Hello uno dos, i want to thank you for a great experience i had last night,since i walked in and i was greeted by one of the cashiers,she saw me that i was kind of lost and asked me : have you been here before? I was so happy she asked, my first time here and she invite me to come closer and started to tell me about all the food and the happy hour bites, i was so exited so i let her choose for me, flautas(yes) 2tacos 1 fish 1 carnitas (yes) ,she also suggested a drink from the bar and chips and guac,i couldn't say no she was smiling and talking to me like she knew me (which i like )  my bar review is also incredible my bartender sandy was so charming and treat me so nice and with a big smile,had a "paloma" and was so delicious, i definitely  coming back, thank you karla and sandy for making me feel so special and uno dos keep up the good job.
author: Margo S.

description: My friend who was visiting me a few weekends ago is obsessed with Tacos and Margaritas. She found this place on Yelp and we went that night. Their margaritas are some of the best margaritas I've ever had and their homemade tortillas are soo good. Seriously, I was so in love with this place I now go here all of the time. While I am thankful for Yelp and my friend for finding this place, my wallet and my weight is not so happy. However, you only live once and you need to live by eating at Uno Dos Tacos.
author: Amanda N.

description: Excellent experience eating here.  All of the staff are very pleasant and food is delicious!  I have some strict dietary needs and the staff were very friendly and helpful accomodating my needs.  Now, I eat here most weekdays for lunch.  I love this place and recommend to everyone I know.
author: Sasha R.

description:
If I make the unfair comparison of Uno Dos to a Mission taqueria, it's overpriced and a bit inauthentic. $3.75 a taco is way more than those hole-in-the-wall taquerias, but it's a decent deal in the FiDi to get lunch for under $10. It's busy but things move quickly, and there's indoor/outdoor seating.

THE WAIT: At noon on a Wednesday, there were about 3-4 in line. We got to the register quickly, and by the time we got our silverware and drinks and sat at our table, our buzzers were going off.

THE COST: $7.34 for two tacos.

* Lengua taco - 3.5 stars
Pretty tender, but a tiny tiny bit rubbery texture-wise. Not too flavorful, but it ends up working with the salsas and the black bean paste they provide. The tortilla is thick, soft, and pretty fresh.

* Carnitas taco - 3.5 stars
Very soft tender meat, but it's way too soggy and drippy, making a bit of a mess when you eat it. As with the lengua, it hasn't got too much flavor on its own and you have to dress it up yourself. I wish they had more salsa options as theirs isn't too spicy.

Lengua + carnitas: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uno-dos-tacos-san-francisco-3?select=wV4KuE8wEh_Qji7CIiqtiA#wV4KuE8wEh_Qji7CIiqtiA
author: Ziyan C.

description: I ended up here really randomly one day with a friend and discovered: a) their happy hour is excellent; b) their tacos are tasty; c) they have indoor and outdoor seating; and d) chicharrones! It's a good place to end up with friends or coworkers - a lot of their spaces are set to accommodate larger and smaller groups. I got the lengua tacos which were fantastic (that Chile verde sauce is bomb) and my friend got the fish tacos which looked phenomenal.
author: Sonya G.

description:
Review for happy hour only, 5p-7p time with friends on a Tuesday:
- guac and chips: one of the best I had! 
- quesadilla: it seemed deep fried but I liked it! 
- ordered 12 tacos: liked the fish the best, very fresh. Agreed with other Yelpers the tortillas got soggy after a bit...just eat fast! :)
- salsa on the tables in the squeeze tub is super spicy, and I liked it!
- fun atmosphere; get there early for a table/seat.

Comparisons:
- Tacos - also like La Taqueria in the Mission (their tacos are hefty - heavy and filling); but I'm not in the Mission much.
- Tacos - if you like street tacos, try the San Buena food truck parked near Sansome and Bush streets M-F in FiDi.
- Guac and chips - really like Celia's guac and chips (in San Bruno on El Camino Real)
author: Mary H.

description:
Average of 3 stars.

4 stars for the breakfast burrito!
I loved it so much I went back for a lunch burrito. Breakfast was better than lunch. 

2 stars for the lunch burrito. The beef burrito I had for lunch was pretty bland and had way too many black beans. I also couldn't taste the guac or sour cream. However, they have amazing hot sauce which I poured into every bite of my burrito.

Highly recommend for a quick and inexpensive breakfast! There's also a fun looking tequila bar, which I didn't partake in but maybe next time.
author: Jenny K.

description: Great for lunch or happy hour. Great salads, friendly service. Blankets for the patio.
author: Vicki L.

description: Does anyone get the runs every single time they eat their breakfast burrito? I'm not sure if it's because they use some type of fake scrambled egg which consists of 80% of the burrito. It seems as if it's made from some quick mix. Or maybe it's the spicy green salsa that you can get with it in its own container. Not sure but it happens every time and it takes up time during the work day when I find myself needing to go to the bathroom multiple times throughout the work day.
author: John C.

description: This is an amazing gem... The food and service was excellent! Monica the manager was very helpful with any questions I had as was the server. Coming back soon!
author: Kenneth F.

description: Been here many times,  love this place for the convenience mainly, but it's a spot you can go to for breakfast, lunch, happy hour and dinner.  I honestly love the guacamole and tomato salsa with chips.  It has the nice flavor to it when you mix both together.  Usually get some tacos to go with the chips, the asada and carnitas are some good options.  Also, the breakfast burritos are cheap and tasty and are about $3.50.  This place gets busy when it's warm outside, cause people love to sit outside and drink margaritas and beers, lol.  Honestly a wonderful place to stop by on the way to the Giants game or before heading home as it is conveniently located close to the Montgomery Bart station.  The one drawback that I have is they do not serve rice in the burritos.  But there's many options of food and drink.  All in all a go to spot when in the area.
author: Jeremaine R.

description: Decent bowls which are well portioned for lunch. The line can get long, and it doesn't move super fast though, so plan ahead. And don't expect to find rice in your bowl.
author: Chris P.

description: Margaritas are BOMB! So are the tacos. Love this place. The fried quesadilla is also super amazingly delicious. My mouth is watering writing this review.
author: Kate C.

description: These tacos are so overrated. The food is overpriced, all the meat is salty, and it takes forever to get alcohol. Standing in two lines is a huge inconvenience. All the people that eat here are loud young obnoxious pseudo professionals.
author: Emily L.

description:
Uno Dos Tacos has fueled my mornings, twice in one week.  They offer a simple menu with Mexican influence with the modern American ambiance and communal seating in a very central location right off Montgomery BART. You can order from the counter for an order to go or choose to stay and eat in. Although Uno Dos Tacos is not as Mexican authentic in decor, they definitely bring on the heat with their homemade salsa and Tapatio Sauce (with influence from Guadalajara). In addition to their friendly customer service their food hits the spot.  

You can't beat their $3.25 breakfast burritos (modest size). Add $.50 for chorizo, veggies or bacon, but they are quite flavorful without. You can also get plain coffee for $2 without the long wait... For now. They do not have speciality coffee drinks. They have Mexican sweet bread and fresh juice.

I hope to try them for happy hour soon. Note in one of my photos they have reasonable prices and decent selection of appetizers. They offer wine and beer and are in the process of getting their liquor license... look out.
author: Nova P.

description: There's something I really enjoy about Uno Dos Tacos - whether it be the food, the simple decor, ambiance, quality ingredients, the drinks, the spacious patio - Uno Dos has it down as a gathering place. I highly recommend anything on their menu; it is a guarantee that no matter what you order, you'll get good quality, fresh food, and for the average Financial District price for a lunch (~$10-12). Uno Dos also has a great happy hour menu consisting of sangrias, margaritas, and chips and dip all at a great price. I love this place; it's centrally located at a busy intersection of the Financial District/SOMA and right next to convenient MUNI and BART lines.
author: Monica M.

description:
It's raining tacos
From out of the sky
Tacos
No need to ask why
Just open your mouth and close your eyes
It's raining tacos...

Fast food taquerias are not an uncommon sight anywhere in this city, but this one has the industrial-strength sheen of Adriano Paganini's other fast food franchise, Super Duper. There's just something very impersonal about the approach in both places that doesn't appear to bother most of their customers. I like the less-than-immaculate mamacita touch you'd find in the Mission because it makes the food taste more authentic. But that doesn't appear to be a priority here. Turnover is, and offering a hipster-friendly selection of fillings. Paganini and his partners took over the shuttered Sellers Market, and people are queuing up at the lunch hour.

I decided to give it a go around 2PM to avoid the crowds, and that worked since I just walked into the cavernous place and ordered (photo: http://bit.ly/1nx1izE). At $3.25 per taco, it adds up, so a trio took me to ten bucks quite easily. They were served up on those familiar metal trays they use at Super Duper as well with a child's serving of black beans and a bit of salsa verde for good measure. I tried the Asada with grilled flap meat and roasted tomato salsa, the Carnitas with slow roasted pork and the same salsa, and the Lengua with braised beef tongue and tomatilla salsa (photo: http://bit.ly/1pkYPYp). They're kinda small, enough to call them taquitos if you ask me.

But they weren't unreasonably priced when I just spent almost double for the same quantity at Tacombi in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Same concept, hipper ambiance. And they were reasonably tasty for how long they lasted. They just lacked distinction much like the burgers at Super Duper. In other words, there was nothing served here that I couldn't have gotten at similarly targeted taquerias. But they get points for convenience. They open at 7AM five days a week and close at 9PM except on Fridays when they close at 10AM for the post-work crowd. They even made the audacious move to stay open Saturdays 10:30AM to 8PM. Not bad for a FiDi location in an office building.

It's raining tacos
Out in the street
Tacos
All you can eat
Lettuce and shell
Cheese and meat
It's raining tacos!

FOOD - 3 stars...good tacos, just not unique but reasonable for the FiDi
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...still looks like Sellers Market to me except for the sliding big door sign
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a bit automatic
TOTAL - 3 stars...tacos from the people who brought you Super Duper, enough said
author: Ed U.

description:
FREAKIN YUM! Loved this place in San Fran! What I really love is that they have outdoor seating with umbrellas.

First off, when you arrive you will order at the counter. They have tacos, burritos, salads, chips, guacamole, salsa, etc.

I ordered two tacos with chips and gwak. The asada taco was so moist and tender. Very flavorful! The pork taco was also amazing! So tasty!

The guacamole was super fresh! Chunks of avocado ~ so amazing.

We went at 12:30 in the afternoon and let me tell you, we didn't have to wait! Gotta love that in downtown San Fran!
author: Kellie M.

description: Giving this place one star because they don't even have a functional phone line. If you want to place a group order or make a group reservation, the only way to do so is by visiting the store in person. Their phone line is an automated voice message redirecting you to their website, which then hangs up.
author: Nahrek H.

description: I came today for happy hour. Great service and good drinks. I recomend the carne asada sopes and the gorditas. We will come back, very nice, after office ambience.
author: Harold F.

description:
I don't like playing the "I grew up with homemade Mexican food so I feel I have room to judge" card, but in this case I will only because after reading comments about this not being "real" Mexican food I'm slightly offended.

This is real Mexican food. I found myself talking to the owner this afternoon, and after telling him that this was some of the best chicken I've ever had, he told me they're all his mother's recipes. I've been to Chipotle, and this was way better than what I've had there - to say you may as well go to Chipotle instead because the flavors are better there... I shake my head and scoff.

I stumbled across this place after seeing it out of the corner of my eye, and was pleased with the very simple menu upon walking in: tacos, burritos, salads, or a plate, with your choice of meat. I went with the chicken plate and it didn't take too long at all to come out; the owner actually brought me my food and gave me some of his red salsa that he makes himself, to try.

The plate was the perfect amount of food, with a pile of shredded, marinated chicken, black beans, pico de gallo, and three homemade corn tortillas. The first bite blew me away. I couldn't get enough of that chicken, and when I'd rip off a piece of tortilla to scoop my beans and salsa with, I'd get a little scoop of perfection in every bite. The green salsa on the table, which looks like maybe a tomatillo based sauce, was spicy and incredibly good.

My complaint was that, while I'm always disappointed by how small corn tortillas are compared to flour, three didn't seem like they were enough. To be honest, they may be enough for someone that doesn't scoop up their food with them, and uses mainly their fork, but when you're relying on your tortillas they disappear fast. I'm not sure how much extra tortillas are, or how many come in an order. Also, $3.75 is steep for one taco. It's the reason why I went with the plate instead, which was a little over eight bucks, but perhaps it wound up better that way in the end.

The simplicity of the meal - meat, beans, tortillas, and salsa - is what made me think of meals I've grown up with, and I appreciated how satisfying such a basic dish could be. 

I can't wait to bring my guy here later this week for dinner. And kudos to the owner for keeping his mom's food alive.
author: Angela M.

description:
This is my favorite breakfast, lunch, and happy hour spot in the Financial District. I have since converted all of my work colleagues and my husband to its deliciousness, as well. I'm not going to pretend like its "super authentic" but I don't expect it to be. If I want authentic, I'll go to La Taqueria, but Uno Dos does not put rice in their burritos (#winning) and their quacamole has a citrus-y quality to it that I can't get enough of. 

I recommend the carnitas: I eat them on salad, in burritos, pretty much on anything. And if you get breakfast, the chorizo breakfast burrito is delicious. At happy hour, make sure to try their margarita, and don't forget to ask for salt on the rim.

I would say the only thing keeping it from 5 stars is that it's always too loud, too crowded, and sometimes the staff is a little rude. But, when the weather allows for it, sitting outside on their patio with a drink and some chips feels like a gift.
author: Daphne W.

description: Solid 3 star downtown taco join. you order at a counter and then pick it up when your disc vibrates. We each got two tacos (beef tongue, pork and fish) and shared a basket of chips with guacamole. All the food was a-ok but nothing memorable.
author: Jordan C.

description: Really love their breakfast burritos, they are not the biggest nor probably the greatest BUT their spicy salsa on top of each bite makes it delicious!! Big props to the Salsa, one of the best I've ever tried. There food smells and looks good I would try other stuff but its a little expensive and its located right at downtown SF so what do you expect?
author: Liset O.

description:
Kinda like Chipotle, but with better booze. Good enough reason for me at least. 

Between lunch and happy hour, I much prefer the latter based on my experiences at Uno Dos Tacos. Perhaps I misread what the plate entailed but I was thinking a rice bowl à la Chipotle thinking that it might be easier to scoff down as I work through lunch but it turned out to be a deconstructed taco plate. Still I thought the asada was flavorful and not too tough or sinewy but I left feeling a little hungry still. Happy hour however is a different story. How about a jalepeno-spiced sangria or $4 drafts to wash down some guacamole and chips? Separate counter for booze makes for shorter lines too. The happy hour vibe, if you can grab a table, is lively but not too packed unlike most other post-work watering holes in the neighborhood. 

I had higher expectations for Uno Dos Tacos since my friend had mentioned that it was good when they were at their pop up location in Russian hill. Not the best taco per se but it will suffice for lunch in a pinch. Nice happy hour though and overall a step up from Seller's Market before.
author: Jon L.

description:
Now if you look at the address here you're not going to find the place. All you'll see is Chase and Peet's coffee. You'll probably also get a hefty dose of urine smell as the BART and homeless gravitate towards this entrance. Go around Stevenson and you'll see a large patio and entrance. 

Adriano Paganini sure keeps building his empire. After Super Duper started going up spreading, he's got yet another concept. Burgers to Mexican. We came late one weekend for find an empty space. Soon after we order a bunch of people show up. I guess we bring the party. Just wanted a snack so we got two tacos and some pineapple drinks. The lengua and pescado are both really solid. It comes with a somewhat bland side of black beans, salsa and a lime. I think the flavors are good but for the two tacos and drinks it was high in price. It looks like the happy hour deals maybe the way to go. However if you want Mexican in the area, this is a welcome addition to what is basically a dearth of the cuisine.
author: Kim N.

description:
I was excited to try a new taco shop by my work that actually serves lengua. I typically only go to one place when the taco craving hits, but they don't serve lengua. I thought this could be a good place to mix it up! 

Came by during my lunch hour this past week. Walking down Market, I realized it's actually located around the corner on 2nd Street and not on Market. So if you're looking for Uno Dos tacos, just get on 2nd and you'll see it.

I ended up getting 2 tacos: Pescado ($4.50) & Lengua ($3.25). The pescado came with wild fried cod and chipotle salsa. The lengua with braised beef tongue and tomatillo salsa. Both on fresh corn tortillas. The pescado was on the smaller side, but nicely fried. I just wish there was more fish since there was so much breading. The lengua was nice and tender. But I wanted a spicier salsa paired with it to give it a kick.

Each table has a bottle of salsa, silverware and napkins. I wish Uno Dos had a salsa bar since I love a good array of salsas. If they did, I'd probably come back more often when a lengua taco craving hits. An okay place for straight up tacos, but I'll probably stick to my other taco spot!
author: Elena N.

description:
Unos Taco? Nooo, DOS tacos, amigos. They want you leaving here with more than one! And their enticing menu definitely made me do that. 

After a short tour around the Yelp Headquarters, my friend Lily S., brought me here for lunch. 

The atmosphere was very classy, yet warm and party like. Love the lights and the decors. 

Tacos were all $3.25-$4.50 each. 

Pescado 4.50: Wild fried cod paired with the chatty chipotle salsa. This was my favorite one out of the two I ordered. Deliciously cooked cod with the right amount of crunch from the fried batter. The chipotle salsa definitely was a good chat with the fried cod. 

Carnitas 3.25: Slow roasted pork dancing with them ratchet roasted salsa. The flavor was there, texture was not. The slow roast pork.. something was off and I cant put my finger on it. 

Anyways, a decent lunch place in the Financial District, but I would never brave the crazy downtown driving to come down here for it.
author: Chena N.

description:
I came here for a quickie meal while everyone I knew was having happy hour at a place that didn't serve real food. I was pleasantly surprised by everything: service efficiency; food quality; and atmosphere. 
Service efficiency: I got my food pretty quickly for how crowded it was
Food quality: I think my quesadilla could have had more cheese and meat but considering I am trying to lose weight and look hot- this was acceptable.
Atmosphere: This place was happening. It was 8pm on a Friday night and I think Uno Dos was where the party was happening.
author: Julianna I.

description:
I mean really what can I say about this place that has the words to describe correctly. Walk in a bit early and I wanted lunch food but they were only serving breakfast. The cashier seeing how heart broken I was offered to take my order if I was ok with waiting 10 mins. I said sure (I mean seriously it's worth it) 

5 minutes later i'm handed this glorious burrito that I know is going to be amazing. They totally broke their own rules to get me my burrito. this is an extra star all on it's own. 

get back to my desk and begin eating. Slapped in the face with delicious chicken and salsa just to be brought down easy by their always melty amazing cheese. ridiculously amazing. 

I walked 3 blocks in the rain without an umbrella and 10/10 would do it again. 
love Uno Dos Tacos
author: Michelle P.

description: Got the chicken bowl it was amazing!! We are from Virginia and wish we had one near us. Great lunch spot
author: Alexandra M.

description:
This place is situated in the PERFECT location for happy hour after a long day of work. To be honest, I did not know what to expect when I came here. We stopped by here because we were obviously too lazy after a long day to walk anywhere else for Mexican food (and because the Happy Hour sign tempted us). 

(+/-) Sangria. $18 +tax for a pitcher ! Not bad for that price if you split it between you and your friends as you sit and chat. I personally like the red wine better than the white wine sangria. The red one definitely went down smoother. 

(+) Tacos. The fish tacos and veggie tacos were bomb(dot)com. Perfectly fried fish and the portions were pretty ok. It is definitely on the pricier side ($4.50 for a fish taco and $3.25 for a veggie one). I tend to make bad money management problems when I'm hungry but it was worth a try! 

(+) Chips & Salsa . $1.95 for a huge basket of salsa was pretty worth it during happy hour.

(+++++) The only thing that I ABSOLUTELY have to give a thumbs up for was the amount of space and seating that the restaurant had. The inside was huge and there were tons of tables outside! The atmosphere is just perfect for a nice drink after work with your colleagues.
author: Tram N.

description:
Ugh...this pains me but I have to write what happened.
I have been trying out Uno Dos' breakfast burritos since they are super convenient, filling, and for $4 quite cheap!
I ordered the burrito with veggies and went back to my office. About 3/4 down into my burrito I was happily noshing and then I bit on something hard......HERB perhaps? That was my first instinct. I then proceed to take this hard piece of something out of my mouth and lo and behold- A PIECE OF BRILLO PAD. *SUPER sad face* I was totally disgusted and brought it back. The manager was apologetic and gave me a refund but seriously left a bad bad bad taste in my mouth. I have found another breakfast burrito spot but deeply saddened I will not be going to Uno Dos anymore.
author: Angela D.

description:
Helllllllo, San Francisco! This will be my first review of an establishment in your locale. Of all of my options I think that I feel most passionately about this review. I was on a recent business trip in the San Francisco region and a coworker of mine took me and a few others out to Uno Dos. Below I will provide you with a comprehensive explanation regarding my experience, and what you may be able to expect from your visit.

Food: I really wanted a burrito, but then ... for the same cost ... I realized that I could get TWO tacos and try TWO different meats! And so the inner-battle for gastrointestinal dominance waged between by stomach and brain. My brain was eloquently piecing together a justifiable and rational explanation regarding its position on the matter, while my stomach was boisterously yelling at my brain like a potty-mouth 5-year-old. Yea, it was ugly.

I finally settled on two tacos -- yep, my brain won. I ordered the carne asada and the carnitas tacos, with guacamole, and with a side of queso. First things first...the meats. The carne asada was excellent. Well-seasoned, tender, and cooked to perfection. The only thing that I like on my carne asada that was not present, was a high heat char from a grill or broiler. Even without that though, this was top-notch. The carnitas were probably the best that I have ever had. Melt-in-your mouth pork, bursting with flavor. I strongly recommend the carinatas. (Meat 5/5)

The homemade corn tortillas were definitely fresh. For me though, I am a flour tortilla guy. If you are a corn-person (that sounds weird)... then go for the corn tortillas -- you will not be disappointed. The guacamole was some of the best I have had in terms of freshness and quality. A little bit too heavy-handed on the chopped onions, but the flavor was on point. Nxt, the side of Queso. This is where an unfortunate circumstance happened. I wanted a side of cheese sauce (i.e. Queso). The dude acted confused by this order, and asked if I wanted melted cheese. I said, 'yes, a cheese sauce.' 

In retrospect, my assumption is that they just don't serve this. Bummer. What I got was a small ramekin of grated cheese. Not gonna penalize them for it, but it was sad. (Tortilla 4, Guacamole 4, cheese N/A)

Ok, so now onto the compilation of the taco. Everything was fresh, the flavors were good, except for the EXCESSIVE serving of chopped onions on the taco. I had to scarpe/pick the vast majority of them out of the taco. There were waaaaay to many. Like, between 1/8 and 1/4 cup on each taco. It was nuts. This was quite disappointing; but easily fixable -- just a nuisance.

Food: 4 / 5

Service: The place was hopping on a Friday afternoon at lunch. Literally, a line out the door and down the street. As such, the main concern for the establishment was quickly fulfilling ticket orders. I get that. It was so busy, that a dude, seemingly a manager of sorts -- was pulling people out of line and ringing them out at the bar. I appreciate that they were doing all that they could to rock-out the voluminous quantity of tickets. As such, I cannot penalize them for lack of service.

Service: 4 / 5

Atmosphere: Waaaaay too busy for my liking; but the overall decor on the inside, and the clean and comfortable area on the outside were really nice. There is indoor and outdoor seating available. indoors it is cramped with all the people hustling about. Outdoors it is also quite cramped. Good luck trying to find a place to sit. Also, do not leave your food for one second! If the aggressive pigeons don't get it, a fast-working bus-person will. The 'bussers' were zooming around very efficiently trying to get things ready for the seemingly endless horde of taco consumers -- so, again, I cannot blame them for being a little over-zealous in their duties.

Atmosphere: 3 / 5

Price: For what I paid, I feel like the quality was fair. For the cost, it did not blow me away; but I would possibly pay it again if I ever came back.

Price: 3 / 5

Final Thoughts: As with all of my reviews, I reserve the right to round up or down. I feel as if Uno Dos is deserving of a 4 star review, despite the minor hiccups in service and food compilation. Overall though, I would say that this is a solid place to grab some tacos and take them back to your office / home / car, etc. Honestly, these tacos are legit, and I fully recommend checking this place out.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Seriously solid lunch spot. The long and short--easily assembled, simple Mexcian food with a massive patio and reasonable prices. If that's not a San Francisco lunch joint, I dunno what is.

When you roll up on the spot there on Market, you may be confronted with a large line. Worry not, that things seems to move pretty quickly. When you get to the front, it's time to assemble your meal. Choose your protein (beef, chicken, pork, fish) or vegetarian, choose your style (served as tacos, burritos, a platter, or salad) and then grab a drink, and go sit down. They give you the old school pager/buzzer/lights, so when it goes off you just go in, and grab your food from the counter.

We added a few extras, including chips, pico, and guac... and that was a good call. Ain't nothing wrong with guac, and they do a nice, limey version. Pico wasn't too acidic, and we killed the whole of it.

As for the food, I went with a fish and a tongue taco. It was the right call, and I loved both of them. The fish won the day, but only just. Seriously, tongue tacos are s'good.

The patio is nice, but obvs it depends on your weather. It can get cramped inside, I would imagine, so take that into consideration.

The best part is the price--you can legit get out the door for under $10 if you're not drinking anything (I've heard they do margaritas now), so your wallet will also thank you.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: One of my favorite happy hours in the city - affordable beers and margaritas and optional food to snack on for the hungrier members of your crowd. Gets busy right after work, but well worth it.
author: Tory C.

description:
Uno Dos Tacos. Not Uno Dos Burritos. Tacos. But I got the burrito. Ugh.

Let me explain.

10:30 in the morning I have a coworker that tells me he's hungry. And I'm like, dude, I'm hella hungry too.

So we leave the building not knowing where we're going. But on the way to lunch the other day, I saw a long line coming out of this interesting looking Mexican restaurant.

Off we go!

Staring up at the menu, I'm not sure what to get. I end up with an asada burrito. It's just OK. There are some really big chunks of meat. The filing is juicy, borderline wet. But the temperature was lukewarm, with a few cold bites.

That's one of my pet peeves, when you expect food to be a certain temperature, and then you bite into a cold spot.

That's what I expect when I reheat three-day leftovers in the microwave. And even then I throw it back into the microwave.

Unfortunately, I'm too lazy to find out if microwaving is an option.

Anyway, I'm having a really good and long conversation with my coworker. And just to let us know we're having too much fun, the waitress rushes by, and without so much as a glance, snaps up our baskets.

So I get back to the office and start thinking about my review. And browsing looking though the pictures, the tacos look really good!

#burritostateofmind suddenly becomes #burritoremorse.

Maybe next time I'll try the tacos.
author: Tony L.

description:
Tacos are good. Execution is ok. 

To start the very kind and apologizing woman at the counter entered 22 carnitas tacos instead of 2. At least my single lengua was a 1. The order came up quick but the basket was a little light. No, not the extra carnitas. Well, actually, yes. I was served up a single tongue and single pork. Good thing I kept my receipt. Oh, this is at 8pm on a Thursday with the house 1/4-1/3 full. This is by no means busy. 

How were the tacos?
Well, I ended up with 2 lengua and solo uno carnitas despite showing the prep girl (the one pulling the food from the cook and making sure it's all good and stuff) my receipt. This was a cluster of an order. 
That said, the pork was good but not great. If you work in a tall building and have never been to an authentic taqueria, you love it. The rest will find it passable for a big city. The tongue was fantastic. If I make it back, that's my bag, man. The tortillas were nice but cooled quickly as it's a single, larger tortilla rather than the traditional, smaller two. "How's the heat?" you ask? "What heat?" I answer. No salsa bar and the green and red are bla. I'd rather a dash of Tapatio.

For its location, I did not expect much and therefor it over performed. The traditional city blankets are serape, so that's fun. This place is loud and the vibe is young, professionals.
